item.title: First day in Vancouver
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Melissa and I arrived in Vancouver around 3 pm. 30 minute wait at the border with no traffic on the drive. Once we got settled in our room on the 30th floor of the Empire Landmark Hotel, we walked down Robson street and explored Granville and Gas Town. After exploring Gas Town, we went to Speakeasy on Granville and both enjoyed Moosehead Lager and Ukranian Pizza(multi-grain crust with potato, garlic, spinach and onion toppings. Delicious!) After we ate, we came back to the hotel for a few hours to rest before heading out to Venue to see Ben Coda and Ad Brown. The music was awesome. Even though Melissa had to come back to the hotel to get her passport (Club security didn’t accept her temp driver’s liscence) the night was a lot of fun. We stayed out till 2:30 and I got to meet Ad Brown and Melissa and I both met Ben Coda (Ad Brown called me a legend for driving all the way up from Seattle to see him and Ben)

item.title: Second day in Vancouver
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Woke up for the day around 11:30 although I got up at 9 am to take pictures of the views from our hotel room because it was a beautiful morning. Once we got up, we took a bus to Granville Island and walked about the Public Market. For lunch, we had doner lamb and some coffee (with lots of whip cream). There was a weird scavenger bird that would not leave Melissa alone, so she named him The Situation. Finally, we went on a mission to find the best pastry in the market. We settled on donuts!

item.title: Last day in Vancouver
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Just got back seeing My Week with Marilyn at the Festival Cinemas. For dinner tonight we had Indian food, which was good, but our waiter was a bit odd so the experience was lacking.

item.title: The Arrival
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My flight arrived in New Orleans around 2:30. Around 5 pm, I finished freshening up and met up with Melissa and we moved her stuff to the Hyatt. (Melissa was already in New Orleans for Society of Behavioral Medicine Conference) After we got settled, we headed to the French Quarter in search of food. We walked down Bourbon Street and down to the water before settling at Ralph and Kakkos, a nice southern-style seafood restaurant. We were served delicious hush puppies and we ordered alligator as an appetizer. It was pretty good! Tasted like fried chicken. For drink, we shared a tropical storm, a specialty drink with lots of alcohol in it. For entrees, Melissa ordered Jumbalaya Pasta and I got fried catfish. Both were delicious! After the meal, we were able to take our alcohol to-go and we walked down by the water and the Bourbon Street before coming back to our hotel. Everybody we have encountered has been super friendly!

item.title: Garden District, French Quarter and Southern Tastes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Melissa and I slept in this morning and didn't get out of the hotel until about 10:45. We planned on taking the St. Charles Street ferry, and on our way, were crossed paths with a crazy person who threw rocks at us. Not a good start to the day, but fitting as it IS Friday the 13th. Luckily, we weren't hit by any of the fist sized rocks thrown our way and we proceeded to get coffee and catch the St. Charles street car to the Garden District. After we got off the crowded street car, we wandered through an above ground cemetery in the Garden District before walking the streets and seeing the mansions the area has to offer. After a while, we got hungry and decided to go to Joey K's - a nice restaurant right next to the Garden District. Melissa ordered a turkey po-boy and I got jumbalaya. It was gooooooood! After lunch, we got some refreshing gelato and then continued to walk around the Garden District before catching the street car back to downtown New Orleans. Once back downtown, we walked around the French Quarter and got a bit lost looking for Frenchmen street. Once we realized it was further than we thought, we turned around, walked along the water and checked out the French Quarter Festival. The festival had lots of good music and good food! We had nachos with Crawfish Mushroom Cream Sauce. It was delicious! After we walked through the festival, we went back to Bourbon Street and enjoyed a grenade. After the grenade we went to Pat O'Brians and listened to dueling pianos while sharing a Hurricane. After that, we walked around for a bit before taking a cab back to our hotel. Overall, very good day :) Edited to add: On our way back to our hotel room somebody ripped ass so loudly and then tried to cover it up by making farting noises with his mouth. It was so obvious what was going on that it was so funny! We walked by and tried not to laugh until we got around the corner. Hilarious!

item.title: Swamp Tours, WW2 Museum, Festivals and Ghost Tours
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Woke up today around 7:30 am and got ready to go on a swamp tour! We were picked up at our hotel at around 9 AM and headed 30 minutes outside of New Orleans to Lafette(sp?) where the tours were. The weather and the tour were great! We rode an airboat out to the swamps and saw lots of alligators, turtles and spanish moss. The guides got the alligators to come to the boat by throwing marshmallows over the side of the boat. The alligators were able to get really close. At one point, the guide reached into an on-board cooler and pulled out his pet alligator, Sally. Melissa and I were able to hold Sally and she was a lot softer than we both thought she would be. Soon after we headed out of the swamp and took the shuttle back to New Orleans. Once back in the city, we went and had lunch at LeBayou on Bourbon Street. Melissa ordered Mufaletta(sp?) and I got Shrimp and Grits. Both were really good and they hit the spot because we were really, really hungry! After lunch we got coffee and headed to the World War II Museum where we caught the film "Beyond all Boundaries". The film and the exhibits in the museum were both really enjoyable and engaging! Afterwards, we again headed back to Bourbon Street where we caught a 2 hour "Ghost and Legends" tour. Our tour guide has been a guide on the history channel and mentioned that we should take lots of pictures because we might catch an apparition on film(We didn't). The highlights of the tour included seeing haunted houses in the French Quarter, including Nicholas Cage's old house. Once the tour concluded, we headed to the French Market and enjoyed fried oyster and fried shrimp po-boy sandwiches to live jazz music. When we were done with dinner, we planned on walking back to Canal Street to catch a cab back to our hotel, but we stopped instead to watch fireworks from the French Quarter festival. We forgot these were happening so this turned out to be a really nice treat :) Walking on Canal Street to catch a cab we noticed that Bourbon Street was REALLY busy because of the festival. We also both noticed light sunburns on ourselves, a sign of a good day in New Orleans :)

item.title: Jazz Cruise and Beignets in the French Market
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Woke up today around 10 AM with not a whole lot on the agenda! Headed to Cafe du Monde where we ate beignets and drank Cafe au Lait(sp?) while we listened to live jazz right next to our table. It was great! After we finished our breakfast, we headed to the waterfront and did our weekly bible study. It was pretty windy and Melissa's hair went all over the place. Funny! After our bible study, we walked to Bourbon Street and bought a few souvenirs and make a quick stop for some gumbo. After gumbo, we walked back to our hotel to rest and refresh for the final activity of our trip: a 2 hour dinner jazz cruise on the Mississippi River on the Riverboat Natchez. We boarded around 6 and the ship departed at 7 pm. It was a really great ride and we enjoyed excellent views of the city. On board we had our fill with chicken, spinach, pork, salad, pasta and potatoes among other things. For dessert we had bread pudding. For drinks, Melissa had an iced tea and I had a MacCallan(sp?) 12 year single malt. It was a great meal. During our meal, I had to get up to go to the 'bathroom', but little did Melissa know that I actually planned on going to the gift shop and getting one final souvenir for the two of us that would help us remember the trip. I ended up getting a mini-riverboat model and she was very happy when she found out :). The crew also loved us, and one crew member in particular remembered who we were from the minute we boarded to the time we got off. We felt like rock stars. Tomorrow we leave and head back to Seattle.

item.title: San Juan Island
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Melissa and I are sitting at a small pub inFriday Harbor called the "Cast and Schooner." Melissa ordered a chicken sandwich and I got fish & chips. Today was our first day on the Islands(San Juan Islands). We left Seattle around 10:45 AM and got here around 4 PM (We got on the ferry in Anacortes around 3 PM). After getting to our campsite at Lakedale Resort(where camping meets glamour!), we set up our tent and drove around the island. Our first stop was English Camp where we saw where the English fort was when they occupied the island. After English Camp, we walked up Young Hill and enjoyed beautiful views of Harrow's Strait and the surrounding islands. After our hike, we went to South Beach and took in beautiful views of the Olympic Mountains. Now are are back in Friday Harbor! The weather has been perfect! Dave looked so hot as he set up the tent today.

item.title: Explore the Island
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Melissa and I are enjoying our second coffee of the day. We both slept OK in the tent and got up around 7 AM. After showering and packing up camp, we boarded the 8:30 ferry to Orcas Island. Once on the island, we drove around and explored including driving to the top of Mt. Constitution and going to the top of the watch tower. The view was great but the weather is a bit cloudy. It is a bit cooler than yesterday. In about 45 minutes, we are going on a whale watching adventure. Should be fun! For breakfast, we ate at a small cafe which served us some interesting(gross) sausage. Hopefully, dinner will be better! We drove by our campsite but it was still occupied so we'll setup later.

item.title: Whale Watching
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Waiting in line to catch the ferry back to Anacortes. Melissa and I were going to stay tonight but decided to skip the long line tomorrow and come home early. This afternoon, we went whale watching where we saw a gray whale named "Spot"(he had a white barnacle that gave him a spot), a few harbor porpoises and sea lions(and maybe 1 seal too). Weather was great with no rain. For dinner, we got sandwiches from a local grocery store and ate outside. Dave snuck beer in a brown paper bag to share. Melissa enjoyed killing ants(at dinner)

item.title: Northeast corner of the United States
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A primary stop on our trip through New England included a 3 hour drive north of Portland, Maine to Acadia National Park.  We spent the day here taking in rugged coast line and views from the highest mountain on the Atlantic coast.  The first thing we did after getting oriented at the visitor center was drive the Park Loop Road, a 27 mile road that takes you through coasts, forests and areas with really nice ocean views and ample opportunity to explore crashing waves and Atlantic tides. After a short drive and a turn onto a one way street, we had ample parking all along the drive to get out of our car and climb along the coast and get close to the water. There are lots of opportunities for photo and video ops!   Eventually, the one way road rejoins with the two way which also makes for a good point to stop and get something to eat.  Luckily, the Jordan Pond House is located there so we were able to refresh and grab a few sandwiches.  After eating, we continued along the Park Loop Road and drove up Cadillac Mountain, the highest mountain on the North Atlantic Seaboard.  From the top we got great views of the surrounding islands and the Atlantic Ocean.  It was a bit windy and cold but still well worth it.  After deciding we had seen everything we wanted to see, we went back to the car and headed south on I-95 back to Portland.

item.title: Exploring Boston
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Driving from Portland, Maine, Melissa and I arrived in Boston around 12:30 PM and checked into our hotel, the Boston Park Plaza.  After we dropped off our rental car at the airport, we took the blue line to downtown and began exploring.  We started off by walking along the Rose Kennedy Greenway near the waterfront near the Boston Aquarium.  After a short walk, we went and visited the Old State House Museum, Faneuil Hall and the Site of the Boston Massacre.    It was quite sunny out so I bought sun glasses at historic Quincy Market to help complete the experience! With the sun out, Melissa and I headed to the Prudential Center to go to the 50th floor observation deck, but the deck was closed for a private party that day. Instead, we walked to Copley Square and rested in the park before heading to the Boston Public Garden and seeing some swans and statues of ducks.  After exploring the garden, we went to Fajitas and Ritas and met with one of Melissa's friends from college.  There we enjoyed fajitas, a massive burrito and some tasty margaritas before we jumped on the T to Kenmore Square to go to Cornwalls, a fun bar not far from Fenway Park.  There we enjoyed good company, beer and watching game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals. After the game finished, we called it a night and headed back to our hotel.

item.title: Hello Lobsters
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Meet Portland, Maine. Small. Quiet. Delicious.  Located just 2 hours north of Boston, Portland makes for a great stop on any New England vacation.  Melissa and I stayed here for two nights and used the city as a jumping off point to Acadia National Park.  A small city with a charming downtown, we enjoyed the delicious food and walking along the waterfront and through brick streets.  We really wanted to get a lobster dinner so we went to the Portland Lobster Company and ordered a tasty Lobster Roll and full Lobster dinner.  It was very good and made for a very memorable time.  If you ever find yourself in Maine looking for a place to explore visit Portland. You'll like what you find.
